citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee failed to notice an adult macaw who is very underweight. There is little to no pectoral muscle mass on his
front. His keel is sharply protruding and visible along the entire length. The bird is in poor feather condition. The licensee
identified the feather condition and is using a treatment, but failed to identify the significant loss of body condition. The
animal is not regularly being weighed. The veterinarian had not been notified. The licensee stated that their new
veterinarian is not comfortable with avian medicine.
A low body condition could be an indicator of a serious underlying health issue.
Exhibitors must provide daily observation of their animals and communicate those observations directly and frequently to
their attending veterinarian so that timely and accurate information of problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being
is conveyed.
To be corrected by: April 31, 2025.

The facility was not able to provide records of acquisitions or inventory for their avian species at the time of inspection.
Appropriate documentation of acquired regulated animals, and complete and accurate records of disposition are essential
for proper identification of losses, and are necessary to track animals used in regulated activities to ensure their humane
care, use, and disposition.
The licensee must maintain acquisition and disposition records for all covered animals, which includes the number of
covered birds held, owned, acquired, or disposed of including births, and deaths. To be corrected by: May 24, 2025.

A wooden shelter in a front enclosure housing two adult Macaws needs replacing. The structure has deteriorated with
several large portions of wood missing and sharp wooden points.
The surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily
cleaned and/or sanitized, or removed and replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces that come in contact with birds
must be free of damage that affects the structural integrity of the surface or prevents cleaning and free of jagged edges or
sharp points that could injure the birds. To be corrected by: May 24, 2025.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, an environmental enhancement plan that is approved by the attending veterinarian has not been
developed by the facility.
An adequate environmental enhancement program is essential in promoting the psychological well-being of birds.
Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote
the psychological well-being of birds, it must be in accordance with the currently accepted professional standards and as
directed by the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by: May 24, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Charles Palmer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee failed to notice an adult macaw who is very underweight. There is little to no pectoral muscle mass on his 
front. His keel is sharply protruding and visible along the entire length. The bird is in poor feather condition. The licensee 
identified the feather condition and is using a treatment, but failed to identify the significant loss of body condition. The 
animal is not regularly being weighed. The veterinarian had not been notified. The licensee stated that their new 
veterinarian is not comfortable with avian medicine.  
 
A low body condition could be an indicator of a serious underlying health issue.  
 
Exhibitors must provide daily observation of their animals and communicate those observations directly and frequently to 
their attending veterinarian so that timely and accurate information of problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being 
is conveyed.  
 
To be corrected by: April 31, 2025. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility was not able to provide records of acquisitions or inventory for their avian species at the time of inspection. 
 
Appropriate documentation of acquired regulated animals, and complete and accurate records of disposition are essential 
for proper identification of losses, and are necessary to track animals used in regulated activities to ensure their humane 
care, use, and disposition. 
 
The licensee must maintain acquisition and disposition records for all covered animals, which includes the number of 
covered birds held, owned, acquired, or disposed of including births, and deaths. To be corrected by: May 24, 2025. 
3.150(c) 
   
Facilities, general.

A wooden shelter in a front enclosure housing two adult Macaws needs replacing. The structure has deteriorated with 
several large portions of wood missing and sharp wooden points.  
 
The surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of materials that allow them to be readily 
cleaned and/or sanitized, or removed and replaced when worn or soiled. Interior surfaces that come in contact with birds 
must be free of damage that affects the structural integrity of the surface or prevents cleaning and free of jagged edges or 
sharp points that could injure the birds. To be corrected by: May 24, 2025. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of inspection, an environmental enhancement plan that is approved by the attending veterinarian has not been 
developed by the facility.  
 
An adequate environmental enhancement program is essential in promoting the psychological well-being of birds. 
 
Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote 
the psychological well-being of birds, it must be in accordance with the currently accepted professional standards and as 
directed by the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by: May 24, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Charles Palmer, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
